title: Maldives–Turkey relations
text:
Maldives–Turkey relations are the foreign <a href="Bilateral%20relation">relations</a> between the <a href="Maldives">Maldives</a> and the <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>. The diplomatic relations were established in 1979. The Turkish Embassy in New Delhi, <a href="India">India</a> is accredited to the Maldives and the Permanent Mission of the Republic of Maldives to the <a href="United%20Nations%20Office%20at%20Geneva">United Nations Office in Geneva</a> is accredited to Turkey. The two countries have good relations between them mostly in the areas of tourism and <a href="Military">defence</a>, while being in close cooperation with one another on international platforms including the United Nations and <a href="Organisation%20of%20Islamic%20Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a> (OIC)
History.
Maldives has benefitted from assistance rendered by Turkey, especially in the aftermath of the <a href="2004%20Indian%20Ocean%20earthquake%20and%20tsunami">2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami</a>. In 2019, in a visit of the Maldivian Minister of Home Affairs <a href="Imran%20Abdulla">Imran Abdulla</a> to <a href="Ankara">Ankara</a>, Turkey vowed to assist with the prison reform in Maldives.
Diplomatic visits.
The first official visit from Turkey to the Maldives since the establishment of diplomatic relations was on 9 February 2005, when Prime Minister <a href="Recep%20Tayyip%20Erdo%C4%9Fan">Erdoğan</a> visited the Maldives in the aftermath of the <a href="2004%20Indian%20Ocean%20earthquake%20and%20tsunami">earthquake and the tsunami disaster in South East Asia on 26 December 2004</a>. The visit to Turkey by Maldivian Foreign Minister <a href="Abdulla%20Shahid">Abdulla Shahid</a> on 15–21 April 2008, was the first official visit from the Maldives to Turkey.
